bibl.note: Colonel I.T.L. Preston wrote to J.G.M. Ramsey on December 27, 1871. He described Lexington’s Confederate cemetery, as being drab and the transportation of Arthur’s remains to Lexington more costly. He suggested that reinterment in Staunton would be a better choice. He requested a copy of Ramsey's "Annals" for his Library. He invited Ramsey and his family to be his guests if they should come to Lexington.

div.p: to him by Dr. M. Donough to Richmond, Va

By an oversight the enclsed has been unduly delayed. It is suffcianty explicit. We have a plot of ground within our county here, to which have been remoed for re-internment the bodies of 30 or 40 soldiers who died at a Hospital hardly, but nothing makes it especially attractive.
Should you for any reason prefer our cemetery to the one mr Stannton,
The additional expense would be $10- or $15 as we have no Rail-Road to our town.
To anything further, cmurnaur my services, and if you and any of your family should come on here, I ask as a favrer That you will be my guests drey your stay
